fields.Title of Contribution: <p><span>Exploring the Impact of Depression, Stress, and </span><span>Sleep Disturbances on Academic Success in </span><span>International College Students</span></p>
fields.Description/Abstract: <p><span>Depression, stress, and sleep issues significantly affect international college </span><span>students'</span><span>academic</span><span>success. This study examines the </span><span>associations</span><span>between </span><span>depression and various academic, mental health, and demographic factors. </span><span>Secondary data analysis was conducted </span><span>for</span><span>13,242 international students </span><span>from </span><span>the 2022 American College Health Association's National College Health </span><span>Assessment (ACHA</span><span>-</span><span>NCHA). </span><span>A total of </span><span>92.7% of the students with moderate to </span><span>high stress reported depression (χ² = 677.038, OR = 6.477 [95% CI (5.532, </span><span>7.585)], p < 0.001), and 52.2% reported sleep issues linked to depression (χ² = </span><span>2075.076, OR = 8.250 [95% CI (7.468. 9.113)], p < 0.001). Acade</span><span>mic stress </span><span>affected 82.7% and anxiety affected 79.8% of </span><span>the </span><span>students (p < 0.001). Higher </span><span>depression rates were found among female students (67.9% </span><span>versus</span><span>32.1% for </span><span>males; p < 0.001), and 20.9% of those facing COVID</span><span>-</span><span>19 challenges reported </span><span>depression. </span><span>This</span><span>study </span><span>underscores the importance of culturally sensitive mental </span><span>health interventions in addressing </span><span>stress</span><span>, sleep issues, and academic pressures </span><span>faced by international students, thereby promoting their success and overall </span><span>well</span><span>-</span><span>being.</span></p>
